audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker introducing himself, mentioning his affiliation with the Australian National University, and stating he will discuss a study on the effect of penis size on male attractiveness. His tone is informative and academic. He notes the study was led by a former PhD student in his group, and that Western culture is obsessed with penis size. He says that you do not have to go far to discover this and notes articles asking "does size matter?" and whether larger penises are better, and mentions an obsession among men which implies penis size is highly advantageous. He then adds that there is a contradiction between emphasis on size and studies saying it does not matter, so he wonders what the truth is.

A male speaker begins by establishing the topic of penis size as a subject of interest across both modern society and historical cultures. He provides examples, mentioning cod pieces from medieval times and a penis gourd worn by a man from New Guinea. The speaker then transitions to the scientific angle, citing reputable scientists such as Jared Diamond and Geoffrey Miller, who have questioned the relatively large penis size in humans compared to other primates. The speaker's tone is academic and informative throughout.

The clip starts with one male speaker posing the question of a correlation between body size and penis size, then describes the rationale behind their research approach. He speaks with a formal, articulate tone, emphasizing a scientific perspective.  The speaker then shifts into a more neutral tone as he discusses the limitations of questionnaires and the need for objective methods. The clip concludes with a mention of finding an answer to the question.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing a study involving male humanoid figures, specifying variations in height, body shape, and penis size within a certain range. The speaker's tone is informational. Following this, the speaker continues by confirming that the range covers most men.

The audio clip begins with a single male speaker emphasizing a point related to previous studies on body shape and height, mentioning "body shape is important," and that females prefer "V-shaped men" and taller men, setting this as a benchmark. He discusses how this information can be used to calibrate the importance of penis size. The speaker then transitions to discussing the extremes of the figures generated in the study, describing the features of the most pear-shaped, shortest figure with the smallest penis, and then the tallest, broadest-shouldered figure with the largest penis.

The audio features a male speaker who explains that figures were presented at "life size" to subjects. He mentions arranging them to move, demonstrating how this subtly increases the ability to perceive the penis size as the individual moves around. The speaker ends by saying, "okay".

The audio begins with a male speaker describing a study. He notes that they "asked 105 women to view full life-sized video images." His tone is informative and academic. He further explains their reasoning for using life-size images, emphasizing the visceral response to size. He contrasts this method with "the more traditional approach of simply asking women to assess figures." A second, male speaker, with a more neutral tone says "Alright."

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing a study where women were asked to rank characters for attractiveness as sexual partners, and notes that women responded "very quickly", taking about three seconds per video. The speech is conversational and informative in tone.

The audio clip features one male speaker. He begins by giving an analogy, describing a scenario where someone is trying to buy a house and has three seconds to choose from a bunch of properties that vary in size, number of bedrooms, price, and distance from the city center. He uses an explanatory and informative tone, explaining how the decision made would reflect the relative importance placed on the different characteristics. He concludes by stating that this is effectively what they've done in the study.

The audio clip features a single male speaker with a neutral tone discussing an analysis, stating it's "uncontroversial" and used in studies of various animals. He mentions applying it to humans, and his background in biology, specifically working with crickets and fish. There are no discernible background sounds or music present.

The audio begins with a single male speaker discussing traits, noting linear or directional selection on body shape, and preference for a V-shaped male. He continues, mentioning height as a predictor of attractiveness, aligning with prior knowledge that "taller men are more attractive." Then, the speaker introduces penis size as also undergoing linear directional selection. He emphasizes the equal importance of height and penis size. The speaker concludes by restating this surprising finding and referencing their study.

The audio features a male speaker addressing a question about penis size, stating that the answer is unknown because the most attractive size was not in their test range. He explains that attractiveness increases with penis size but starts to plateau, not reaching a peak in their data. He concludes that the most attractive size is larger than that found in most men.

The clip starts with one male speaker sharing an "interesting fact," mentioning that females ranked males with different penis sizes quickly, not consciously, but it "simply happened". He elaborates that females quickly dismissed a small penis as "unattractive" and moved on. There are no background sounds in the clip.

An academic male voice starts the audio clip, providing a summary of how character interactions affect each other. He references an X-axis showing "height" of individuals, and a Y-axis showing "penis size". He continues to explain that this is like a contour map that joins values of "attractiveness". The color red is "high ground" and means "sexy." He then explains that a very tall individual with a very large penis is the most attractive. He also mentions that a short individual with a small penis is the least attractive and calls that individual "blue, unattractive". He continues to say that a short individual's attractiveness remains largely unchanged as "penis size" increases. For a tall individual, as penis size increases, they are going uphill and become more attractive. The speaker mentions in sum that penis size matters more for tall males than for short males. He concludes that the findings are similar regarding body size, or "body shape" (V-shaped or pear-shaped), showing similar relationships.

The clip features a male speaker summarizing research findings, emphasizing support for previous studies about attractiveness factors such as height and body shape. He discusses new results, including diminishing returns and trait interactions, and concludes by stating "penis size does matter, no matter what they say". The speaker presents the information in a matter-of-fact tone.

The audio clip consists of a single male speaker who expresses gratitude with the phrase "Thank you for listening," followed by a farewell "Goodbye." His tone is neutral and conversational. No other sounds are present.
